user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ModuleUnload:
```c
int32 OS_ModuleUnload(osal_id_t module_id)
{
    OS_module_internal_record_t *module;
    int32                        return_code;
    OS_object_token_t            token;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_EXCLUSIVE, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, module_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        module = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_module_table, token);

        /*
         * Only call the implementation if the file was actually loaded.
         * If this is a static module, then this is just a placeholder and
         * it means there was no file actually loaded.
         */
        if (module->module_type == OS_MODULE_TYPE_DYNAMIC)
        {
            return_code = OS_ModuleUnload_Impl(&token);
        }

        /* Complete the operation via the common routine */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(return_code, &token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_ModuleUnload:
typedef struct
{
    char             module_name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    char             file_name[OS_MAX_PATH_LEN];
    OS_module_type_t module_type;
    uint32           flags;
    cpuaddr          entry_point;
} OS_module_internal_record_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_module_internal_record_t OS_module_table[OS_MAX_MODULES]
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
int32 OS_ModuleUnload_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32                             status = OS_ERROR;
    OS_impl_module_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_module_table, *token);

    /*
    ** Attempt to close/unload the module
    */
    dlerror();
    if (dlclose(impl->dl_handle) == 0)
    {
        impl->dl_handle = NULL;
        status          = OS_SUCCESS;
    }
    else
    {
        OS_DEBUG("Error unloading shared library: %s\n", dlerror());
    }

    return status;
}
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(int32 operation_status, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    osal_id_t final_id;

    /* Clear the OSAL ID if successful - this returns the record to the pool */
    if (operation_status == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        final_id = OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED;
    }
    else
    {
        /* this restores the original ID */
        final_id = token->obj_id;
    }

    /* Either way we must unlock the object type */
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, &final_id);

    /* Give event callback to the application */
    if (operation_status == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_NotifyEvent(OS_EVENT_RESOURCE_DELETED, token->obj_id, NULL);
    }

    return operation_status;
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_module_table, *token);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario:
No violation in the shown code as written. OS_ModuleUnload_Impl declares its parameter as const OS_object_token_t *token, and the expression used (OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_module_table, *token)) effectively passes the address of that const object; provided the underlying helper OS_ObjectIndexFromToken and the macro accept a pointer-to-const, const-correctness is preserved. 

Potential violation scenario: If OS_ObjectIndexFromToken (or any function invoked by the macro expansion) is declared to take a non-const OS_object_token_t * (i.e. it does not accept a const-qualified pointer), then using *token (which has type const OS_object_token_t) causes an attempt to pass a const-qualified object to a non-const parameter, discarding const qualification. In that case Rule 8.13 would be violated. The fix would be to change those APIs to take const OS_object_token_t * (or to avoid dropping const in the macro).
